questions.text: Hawkins’s classification is used for which fractures?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Talus Hawkins’s classification is used to describe fracture of neck of talus. Hawkins classification: Type Description Hawkins I Nondisplaced Hawkins II Subtalar dislocation Hawkins III Subtalar and tibiotalar dislocation Hawkins IV Subtalar, tibiotalar, and talonavicular dislocation

questions.correct_answer: A. Avulsion of the anteroinferior glenoid labrum
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Avulsion of the anteroinferior glenoid labrum Bankart lesion is avulsion of the labrum from anterior inferior glenoid rim . It is the m/c lesion associated with anterior dislocation of the shoulder joint . Bankart lesion is an avulsion in the anteroinferior part of the glenoid labrum caused due to the recurrent anterior dislocation of the humeral head. Hill-Sachs lesion is a compression fracture on the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head. It is caused by the pressure of the anterior glenoid rim on the humeral head in recurrent dislocations. Anterior dislocation is the commonest shoulder dislocation and can be caused due to trauma from behind the shoulder pushing the head out anteriorly. It is also caused due to falling on an outstretched hand in an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. It can be diagnosed on clinical examination with flattening of the shoulder contour and ability to place a rule (Hamilton ruler test) and the inability to touch his/her opposite shoulder (Duga's test). X- ray confirms the diagnosis and may show associated Hill Sachs or bony bankart lesion. The most common complication is recurrent shoulder dislocation.

Highyeild:

Complication of shoulder dislocation There are common to all three types of dislocations. The most common complication of the shoulder dislocation is recurrence The most common acute complication is axillary nerve injury, which leads to loss of sensation on lateral aspect of arm (regimental badge sign) and loss of motor power to deltoid and teres minor. Recurrence of anterior dislocation of shoulder Produces two lesions Hill Sach's lesion: On posterolateral superior aspect of humeral head Bankart's lesion on anterior surface of the glenoid Recurrence of posterior dislocation produces, reverse hill Sach’s lesion also k/a McLaughlin's lesion.

questions.text: In which of the following fractures does the three-point bony relationship is maintained?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Supracondylar fracture humerus The 3-point bony relationship of the elbow is formed by the medial & lateral epicondyles of humerus & the olecranon of the ulna. It is well preserved in the supracondylar fracture of the humerus. 3 Point Bony Relationship( in flexion and extension Elbow joint) Nerve and vessel injury : Most common nerve to be injured in Extension type - anterior interosseous nerve > Median nerve > Radial nerve > Ulnar nerve. (AMRU) Most common nerve to be injured in Flexion type - Ulnar nerve. Most common vessel to be injured - Brachial artery. The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks. Conditions where 3 Point Bony Relationship not maintained: Fracture olecranon Elbow dislocation Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle Intercondylar fracture of humerus

questions.text: A female patient presented with swollen and tender joints. There is symmetric involvement of multiple joints such as wrists, hands, and feet, which is bilateral, along with morning stiffness lasting more than 1 hour. Erythema is absent. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

RA (Rheumatoid arthritis) All of the given clinical features are characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis. RA - It involves the proximal interphalangeal joint, metacarpophalangeal joint, and wrist and spares distal interphalangeal joint.

Highyeild:

Characteristic deformities of the hand in Rheumatoid Arthritis include: Z deformity - Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of the digits Swan - neck deformity - Extension contracture of PIP joints with compensatory flexion of DIP joints Boutonniere deformity - flexion of PIP joints with the extension of DIP joints. Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), plantar subluxation of metatarsal heads, widening of the forefoot, hallux valgus, and lateral deviation and dorsal subluxation of toes; hammer toe. Wind-sweep deformities of toes, i.e. valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in other (as the wind sweeps all the structure in one direction)

questions.text: What type of gait will be seen following a fracture in this region?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High stepping The marked area is neck of the fibula. Injury to the common peroneal nerve is associated with fracture of neck of the fibula. This nerve lesion results in foot drop (plantar flexion & inversion of foot) & High stepping gait ( foot drop gait) As to lift the dropped foot while walking there is exaggerated knee & hip flexion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Waddling gait is seen in developmental dysplasia of the hip and in proximal muscle weakness. Option: B . Wide-stepping gait is a broad-based unstable gait and is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction. Option: C . Stamping of the foot is seen in tarsal tunnel syndrome. Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a condition with pain and sensory disturbance occurring in the medial part of the forefoot, unrelated to weight-bearing. This is due to compression of the posterior tibial nerve behind and below the medial malleolus. Typically the pain worsens at night and gets relieved on walking or stamping the foot.

questions.text: Choose the true statements: The most commonly fractured carpal bone is the lunate The scaphoid is most commonly fractured at the wrist The cast for scaphoid fracture is set in a glass- holding position Kienböck’s diseases is due to osteonecrosis of the lunate. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.correct_answer: A. ii, iii and iv only
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ii, iii and iv only Statement i : The most commonly fractured carpal bone is the lunate is a false statement. The most commonly fractured bone in the wrist is the scaphoid bone . Statement ii : The scaphoid is most commonly fractured at the wrist is a true statement. A scaphoid fracture is more common in young adults. Commonly, the fracture occurs through the waist of the scaphoid carpal bone . Statement iii : The cast for scaphoid fracture is set in a glass holding position is a true statement. The affected hand is immobilized in a scaphoid cast for 3-4 months. The scaphoid cast extends from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads including the thumb up to the inter-phalangeal joint . The wrist is maintained in a little dorsiflexion and radial deviation ( glass holding position ). Statement iv : Kienböck's disease is due to osteonecrosis of the lunate is a true statement. Kienböck's disease is usually seen in young adults, who present with pain and stiffness in the wrist. Limited and painful wrist movements are noted in the later stages of the disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a tibial fracture in a cast presented to the emergency department with complaints of intense pain. The cast was removed and on examination, passive extension was painful. The dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses were present and there was a loss of sensation over the first web space. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Measure anterior compartment pressure The diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressure using a catheter introduced into the compartment. The difference between diastolic pressure and compartment pressure is known as differential pressure . If the differential pressure is less than 30 mm Hg, immediate compartment decompression is indicated.

Highyeild:

The classic features of ischemia in acute compartment syndrome include the 5 Ps : Pain : is the first symptom of acute compartment syndrome. On passive stretching of the muscles, severe pain can be elicited. Paresthesia: paresthesia and hypoesthesia are the first signs of nerve ischemia. Paralysis : paralysis of muscle groups affected in that compartment is a late sign. Pulselessness : usually, the peripheral pulses and capillary return are intact in the early stages, unless there is a major arterial injury. If pulses are absent, arteriography is indicated. Pallor : may not always be seen as ischemia occurs at the capillary level. Treatment include: Decompression of the affected compartment is done immediately. All the dressings, bandages, and cast on the affected limb are removed. Fasciotomy is done if the differential pressure is less than 30 mm Hg Fasciotomy wounds are left open and observed after 2 days. If there is necrosis, debridement is done. If the wounds are healthy, they can be sutured without tension or skin grafting can be done.
